Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Adjuvant Treatment Strategies Following Neoadjuvant Chemoimmunotherapy in Resectable NSCLC

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were categorized into no-treatment (n=46), chemotherapy (ChT) (n=38), immunotherapy (IT) (n=33), chemoimmunotherapy (ChIT) (n=168), and upfront surgery with adjuvant immunotherapy (US+AIT) (n=32) groups.

Participants.evidence: 317 patients with stage IB-IIIB NSCLC treated at Shandong Cancer Hospital from January 2019 to February 2024.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were categorized into no-treatment (n=46), chemotherapy (ChT) (n=38), immunotherapy (IT) (n=33), chemoimmunotherapy (ChIT) (n=168), and upfront surgery with adjuvant immunotherapy (US+AIT) (n=32) groups.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate adjuvant treatment strategies following neoadjuvant chemoimmunotherapy (NCIT) in patients with resectable non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).

Method_Outcome.evidence: Event-free survival (EFS) and overall survival (OS) were primary outcomes, assessed over a median follow-up of 30.7 months.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 317 patients with stage IB-IIIB NSCLC treated at Shandong Cancer Hospital from January 2019 to February 2024.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Patients were categorized into no-treatment (n=46), chemotherapy (ChT) (n=38), immunotherapy (IT) (n=33), chemoimmunotherapy (ChIT) (n=168), and upfront surgery with adjuvant immunotherapy (US+AIT) (n=32) groups.

Result_Outcome.evidence: IT and ChIT groups showed improved EFS compared to the no-treatment group.

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported.
